sections.title: Overview
sections.content: Georgia is a country located at the crossroads of Eastern Europe and Western Asia, in the Caucasus region. It is known for its ancient history, unique language, mountainous landscapes, and strong cultural identity.

sections.title: Capital City
sections.content: Tbilisi is the capital and largest city of Georgia. It is known for its historic old town, diverse architecture, and vibrant cultural scene.

sections.title: Currency
sections.content: The official currency of Georgia is the Georgian lari (GEL).

sections.title: Language
sections.content: The official language is Georgian, which has its own unique alphabet. Minority languages are also spoken, and English is increasingly used among younger generations.

sections.title: Traditional Food
sections.content: Georgian cuisine is famous for its rich flavors and use of herbs, with popular dishes including khachapuri, khinkali, and lobio.

sections.title: Geography
sections.content: Georgia has diverse geography, ranging from the high peaks of the Greater Caucasus Mountains to fertile valleys and a Black Sea coastline.

sections.title: Culture
sections.content: Georgian culture emphasizes hospitality, traditional polyphonic singing, dance, and a deep connection to Orthodox Christianity and ancient traditions.

sections.title: Tourism
sections.content: Tourism highlights include the Caucasus Mountains, ancient monasteries like Gergeti Trinity Church, the historic city of Mtskheta, and wine regions such as Kakheti.

sections.title: Fun Fact
sections.content: Georgia is considered one of the oldest wine-producing regions in the world, with winemaking traditions dating back over 8,000 years.

history.event: Early civilizations emerged in the region, laying the foundations of Georgian culture.
Christianity was adopted as the state religion, making Georgia one of the earliest Christian nations.
The unified Kingdom of Georgia experienced a golden age of political power, culture, and architecture.
Georgia fragmented into several kingdoms and principalities due to invasions and internal conflicts.
The Kingdom of Kartli-Kakheti was annexed by the Russian Empire.
Georgia declared independence following the collapse of the Russian Empire.
Georgia was incorporated into the Soviet Union.
Georgia regained independence after the dissolution of the Soviet Union.
A brief war with Russia occurred over the regions of South Ossetia and Abkhazia.
